bibl.author: Various
bibl.title: The fugitive miscellany. Being a collection of such fugitive pieces, in prose and verse, as are not in any other collection. With many pieces never before published.
bibl.note: The hit for poe was the word poem, but when you search inside the work for Otaheite you get a poem that was written as though it were from Oberea to Banks. It might be worth looking at because it references actual events from the voyage logs.

bibl.author: Fitzgerald, Gerald.
bibl.title: The injured islanders; or, the influence of art upon the happiness of nature.
bibl.pubPlace: London, MDCCLXXIX. [1779]. Eighteenth Century Collections Online. Gale. University of Pittsburgh Libraries
bibl.note: This one is already on the Obdurodon site but I figured I'd leave it on the list just in case.

bibl.author: Alexander, William (d. 1783)
bibl.title: The history of women, from the earliest antiquity, to the present time; giving some account of almost every interesting particular concerning that sex, among all nations, ancient and modern. By William Alexander, M.D. In two volumes.
bibl.editor: London : printed for W. Strahan, and T. Cadell, in the Strand, MDCCLXXIX. [1779].
bibl.note: Not sure if we should keep this one or not. It seems to draw a lot of information from the voyage accounts but doesn't summarize them as much as other works.

bibl.title: Omiah's farewell; inscribed to the ladies of London.
bibl.publisher: printed for G. Kearsly, in Fleet-Street, MDCCLXXVI.
bibl.note: Worth keeping because it is an example of a poem that was written using the voyage accounts rather than just a summary.
